questions.question: What is the main focus of the study described in the text?
questions.answer: The main focus of the study is the depolymerization of polyesters by a binuclear catalyst for plastic recycling.

questions.question: What type of catalyst is used for the degradation of poly(ethylene terephthalate) (PET) and other plastics?
questions.answer: A binuclear complex is used as the catalyst for the degradation of PET and other plastics.

questions.question: What is the specific activity of the binuclear zinc catalyst towards PET depolymerization at pH 13 and 90°C?
questions.answer: The specific activity of the binuclear zinc catalyst towards PET depolymerization at pH 13 and 90°C is 577 gPET h−1 gcatal−1.

questions.question: Is the binuclear zinc catalyst effective in natural seawater for PET depolymerization?
questions.answer: Yes, the binuclear zinc catalyst is effective in natural seawater for PET depolymerization.

questions.question: What is the role of water molecules in the catalytic process of PET depolymerization by the binuclear zinc catalyst?
questions.answer: Water molecules play essential roles in stabilizing the under-coordinated Zn atom and strengthening Zn–O(EGD) binding in the catalytic process.

questions.question: Can the binuclear zinc catalyst be used for the closed-loop production of bottle-grade PET?
questions.answer: Yes, the binuclear zinc catalyst can be used for the closed-loop production of bottle-grade PET.

questions.question: What is the space-time yield of terephthalate using the Zn2/C catalyst at pH 13 and 90°C?
questions.answer: The space-time yield of terephthalate using the Zn2/C catalyst at pH 13 and 90°C is 50–70 g l−1 h−1.

questions.question: Does the binuclear zinc catalyst show tolerance to various additives and impurities?
questions.answer: Yes, the binuclear zinc catalyst shows excellent tolerance to various additives and impurities.

questions.question: What is the turnover number of the Zn2/C catalyst after 15 cycles of reuse?
questions.answer: The turnover number of the Zn2/C catalyst after 15 cycles of reuse is greater than 25,000.

questions.question: Is the binuclear zinc catalyst capable of degrading Nylon 66?
questions.answer: Yes, the binuclear zinc catalyst is capable of degrading Nylon 66.

questions.question: What is the percentage of zinc loss per cycle after the first cycle of using the Zn2/C catalyst?
questions.answer: The percentage of zinc loss per cycle drops below 1% after the first cycle of using the Zn2/C catalyst.

questions.question: Does the structure of the spent Zn2/C catalyst remain the same after use?
questions.answer: Yes, the structure of the spent Zn2/C catalyst remains the same after use.

questions.question: What is the net profit generated from the PET recycling process using the Zn2/C catalyst on 0.1 megatons of PET waste per year?
questions.answer: The net profit generated from the PET recycling process using the Zn2/C catalyst on 0.1 megatons of PET waste per year is US$26.0 million.

questions.question: Can the binuclear zinc catalyst depolymerize polybutylene adipate terephthalate (PBAT)?
questions.answer: Yes, the binuclear zinc catalyst can depolymerize polybutylene adipate terephthalate (PBAT).

questions.question: What is the role of the μ2-O bridged binuclear zinc sites in the catalytic process?
questions.answer: The μ2-O bridged binuclear zinc sites are critical for the stabilization of the six-membered ring intermediate in the catalytic process.

questions.question: Is the binuclear zinc catalyst effective in depolymerizing high-crystalline PET?
questions.answer: Yes, the binuclear zinc catalyst is effective in depolymerizing high-crystalline PET.

questions.question: What is the crystallinity of the post-consumer PET water bottles used in the study?
questions.answer: The crystallinity of the post-consumer PET water bottles used in the study is 25%.

questions.question: Does the binuclear zinc catalyst require a high concentration of alkali for effective PET depolymerization?
questions.answer: No, the binuclear zinc catalyst does not require a high concentration of alkali for effective PET depolymerization.

questions.question: What is the energy cost of the most endothermic step in the DFT-calculated PET depolymerization process on Zn2L(OH)2?
questions.answer: The energy cost of the most endothermic step in the DFT-calculated PET depolymerization process on Zn2L(OH)2 is only 0.64 eV.

questions.question: Can the binuclear zinc catalyst depolymerize polycaprolactone (PCL)?
questions.answer: Yes, the binuclear zinc catalyst can depolymerize polycaprolactone (PCL).
